TOP STORIES

Advertisement

Advertisement

Advertisement

People of color report widespread racism in EU

The European Union has little ground for finger-pointing when it comes to racism. EU countries are by no means free of discrimination and violence — and calls for change are growing louder.  Go to article  

Racism in Germany 'an issue for society as a whole'

DW spoke to Dr. Karamba Diaby, Germany's first African-born black MP, about the global anti-racism protests and related developments in Germany. "Unfortunately, much needs to be done," the parliamentarian tells DW.  

Germany to launch study into police racism

The German government will look into the alleged "racial profiling" after a senior lawmaker claimed "latent racism" in the ranks of the German police. Other officials warned against equating Germany and the US.  

'If you're silent, you're against us'

The US national team goalkeeper, currently on loan at Düsseldorf, has had enough of police brutality and racism.  

Child laborers caught between coronavirus and economic hardship

In South Asian nations like Pakistan, where child labor is rampant, COVID-19 has brought more hardship to underage workers. Meanwhile, the resulting economic crisis is pushing even more children into child labor.  

CORONAVIRUS AROUND THE WORLD

Coronavirus latest: India now fourth worst-hit nation

The South Asian country has recorded almost 300,000 infections, behind only the US, Brazil and Russia. Meanwhile, the UN has warned the pandemic could cause a spike in child labor. Follow DW for the latest.  

Turkey decries Germany's extended warning

Ankara is frustrated that Germany has failed to lift its coronavirus travel warning for Turkey, just as borders within the European Union start to reopen. Berlin stretched warnings for over 160 countries on Wednesday.  

Coronavirus dampens Germans' travel enthusiasm

On June 15, Germany's travel warning for most European countries will be lifted. But how willing are Germans to travel?  

Does coronavirus kill fewer people in East Asia?

People in East Asia seem to be less likely than those in many other parts of the world to die of the coronavirus. But the explanations that have been put forward do not all hold water, as Martin Fritz reports from Tokyo.  

Health budgets: Will the pandemic change Kenya's priorities?

Health is seen as one of the winners in Kenya's annual budget. Many in Kenya's health circles however argue that the COVID-19 crisis has simply highlighted the underfunding of the sector in past years.  

A devil's bargain for Dutch sex workers

Public health measures to curb the spread of the coronavirus have hit the Dutch domestic sex industry hard. Some of Amsterdam's sex workers continue to work illegally, risking their health to make ends meet.  

NEWS REPORTS

UK formally rejects Brexit talks extension 2h ago

The UK will not ask for more time to reach a deal with the EU on their post-Brexit relationship, the UK's top Brexit official Michael Gove has confirmed. However, the UK also softened its stance on border checks.  

France: Police protest against chokehold ban, racism accusations 6h ago

A chokehold ban planned by France's interior minister has prompted nationwide police protests. Officers in Paris downed handcuffs and displayed a banner declaring "no police, no peace."  

At least 53 dead in migrant shipwreck off Tunisia 7h ago

Rescue operations have recovered 53 bodies after a vessel carrying migrants capsized off the coast of Tunisia. The passengers had been fleeing tensions caused by the conflict in Libya.  

ICC slams US sanctions over war crimes probe 7h ago

The Trump administration has sanctioned International Criminal Court employees investigating whether US troops committed war crimes in Afghanistan. The ICC accused the US of trying to "interfere with the rule of law."  

Trump row escalates over Seattle protest zone 10h ago

An "autonomous" protest camp in Seattle has stoked a verbal battle between the city and US President Donald Trump, who has threatened to send in the military. Mayor Jenny Durkan told him to "go back to your bunker."  

Twitter removes accounts linked to China, Russia 16h ago

Twitter said the accounts were part of a network used to push propaganda, attack critics of the government and spread misinformation. A majority of the accounts were linked to China.  

STORIES & ANALYSIS

Syria currency crisis: Idlib facing disaster

Amid Syria's currency crisis, a new round of US sanctions against the Assad regime is due to come into force shortly. As life is getting worse for people in rebel-controlled Idlib, many still support the sanctions. Why?  

Lebanon in currency crisis as protests spread across the country  

Neo-Nazi murder of Alberto Adriano remembered, 20 years on

Dessau is notorious for two brutal deaths of Africans in separate incidents — one of which occurred in police custody and remains unresolved. Even today, few of the city’s white residents see racism as a daily problem.  

Perspectives

Putin's anti-gay agenda

Russian leaders are exploiting homophobia to get people to participate in a referendum, DW's Juri Rescheto writes.  

Most Read

Kashmir conflict photographer Masrat Zahra wins top photojournalism award

Germany extends travel warnings for 160 countries

Coronavirus: A devil's bargain for Dutch sex workers

Netherlands sends first herring catch to German medics as coronavirus thank you

DW English Live

DocFilm - GSG 9 - Germany’s Counterterrorism Unit

Coming up at 19:00 UTC: DW News

COVID-19: Waiting for a wonder drug

All over the world, scientists are rushing to find a drug to treat COVID-19 - but the road to discovery is far from straightforward. Watch the latest edition of DW's COVID-19 special coverage.  

Advertisement

Bolsonaro taken to court over deforestation

Experts predict a double catastrophe in the Amazon rainforest if the coronavirus pandemic overlaps with the forest fire season. The Brazilian government has frozen climate funds and rolled back environmental regulations.  

Extinction Rebellion: Militancy despite pandemic

XR activists are labelled as rebels or fanatics. Provocation is their unique selling point and more major demonstrations lie ahead. But will people listen to their message at a time of coronavirus pandemic?  

Hope for recovery as extinction Red List grows

While endangered species such as the spiny seahorse have started to recolonize former habitats due to coronavirus lockdowns, a new study confirms that the number of extinction-threatened species is rising fast.  

Coronavirus threatens Japan's hanko seals

For centuries, the hanko have served as the official mark of companies, organizations and individuals. The COVID-19 health crisis has pushed Japan to realize that technology can be deployed for convenience and speed.  

A woman's perspective of the Kashmir conflict

Kashmir-based reporter Masrat Zahra told DW that the conflict in the region has always been told from a man's viewpoint. This year's winner of the Anja Niedringhaus Courage in Photojournalism Award wants to show a different side.  

Why all the fuss about hydrogen?

Germany wants to become the world leader in hydrogen technology as it strives to spearhead a drive to meet its energy needs with the most abundant element in the universe. Here's what's so astonishing about hydrogen.

Indian women discover scooters

The necessity for increased mobility is helping Indian women win new freedom and overcome stereotypes.  

On the Wittelsbach trail in royal Munich

For centuries, the noble family of Wittelsbach controlled the fate of Bavaria and thus also of Munich. The dukes, electors and kings left their mark on the cityscape ⁠— much to the delight of tourists.  

COVID-19 a chance to transform the world? 12.06.2020

DW's Neil King and Gabriel Borrud explore whether the pandemic could be a catalyst for real and sustainable change.

Subscribe to Corona Compact

Countries across Asia are continuing to battle COVID-19, and DW's newsletter is here with trustworthy and accurate information on the pandemic's social and economic impact. Subscribe now, find out more, and stay healthy.
